<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.

Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.

<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_tortoise_detectcycles:
```c
static int lfs_tortoise_detectcycles(
    const lfs_mdir_t *dir, struct lfs_tortoise_t *tortoise) {
    // detect cycles with Brent's algorithm
    if (lfs_pair_issync(dir->tail, tortoise->pair)) {
        LFS_WARN("Cycle detected in tail list");
        return LFS_ERR_CORRUPT;
    }
    if (tortoise->i == tortoise->period) {
        tortoise->pair[0] = dir->tail[0];
        tortoise->pair[1] = dir->tail[1];
        tortoise->i = 0;
        tortoise->period *= 2;
    }
    tortoise->i += 1;

    return LFS_ERR_OK;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_tortoise_detectcycles:
struct lfs_tortoise_t {
    lfs_block_t pair[2];
    lfs_size_t i;
    lfs_size_t period;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragments violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. The only function parameters are the pointers 'dir' and 'tortoise'. The code does not reassign either pointer variable (no statements like 'tortoise = ...' or 'dir = ...'), nor does it perform pointer arithmetic on them. All modifications are to the objects pointed-to (e.g., tortoise->pair[0], tortoise->pair[1], tortoise->i, tortoise->period), which is permitted by the rule. The 'dir' parameter is declared const and only read. The call to lfs_pair_issync passes pointers but does not modify the parameter variables in this function. Therefore there are no suspicious fragments to investigate under Rule 17.8.
